geoclaw.datatools package¶

Submodules¶

geoclaw.datatools.fixdata module¶

fixdata¶

Provides functions for removing erroneous data from arrays as grids

Contains:
findbadindices fillbaddata
geoclaw.datatools.fixdata.fillbaddata(Z, badinds)[source]¶

fill data in array Z, at indice tuples in list badinds by averaging surrounding good data. return new array.

geoclaw.datatools.fixdata.filterdata(Z, filterinds, radius=1)[source]¶

filter data in array z, at indice tuples in list filterinds by averaging surrounding data, ball with radius=radius in inf-norm acts as a low-band pass filter and removes oscillatory data

geoclaw.datatools.fixdata.findbadindices(Z, badvalue=inf, removenans=True)[source]¶

remove nans or infs from an array

geoclaw.datatools.iotools module¶

iotools¶

Provides several useful functions for easy input and output from data files

Contains:
convertd2e datafile2array array2datafile
geoclaw.datatools.iotools.array2datafile(dataarray, datafile=' ', sep='')[source]¶

def array2datafile (array,datafile=” “):

output a tuple, list or numpy array into a ascii text file. The number of rows and columns in the data file will match the size of the array.
geoclaw.datatools.iotools.convertd2e(numberstring=' ')[source]¶

def convertd2e (numberstring):

takes a string and replaces all d’s or D’s with e’s. usefule for reading data files with doubles output by Fortran, which uses d, or D instead of e, for the exponent.
geoclaw.datatools.iotools.datafile2array(datafile=' ', sep=None, dtype='float', skiplines=0, skipfirstcols=0, skiplastcols=0)[source]¶

open and read data from a ascii text file into a numpy array. The number of rows and columns in the data file will match the size of the array.

sep is the character seperation between fields in the data file dtype is the how the file data is to be interpretted. skiplines = n skips the first n line(s). skipfirstcols = n skips the first n column(s) skiplastcols = n skips the last n column(s).
